title: MOST • MOST OF • THE MOST • MOSTLY • ALMOST • ALMOST ALL • NEARLY
subtitle: Structure • Example • Short Explanation

subsections.title: MOST + plural noun / uncountable noun
examples: Most people work during the day.
Most sand is yellow.
A few people didn't pay, but most did.

subsections.title: MOST OF + determiner + plural / uncountable noun
structure: (determiner = the, this, that, my, your, his, her, etc.)
examples: I get most of my news from Facebook.
Most of his books are set in Roman times.
Most of the people arrived early.
subsections.explanation: More specific than 'most.' Must include a determiner — except with countries/cities.

subsections.title: MOST OF + country/city (no determiner needed)
examples: Most of South Korea is surrounded by water.
subsections.explanation: Countries and cities can follow 'most of' directly.

subsections.title: THE MOST + long adjective (3+ syllables)
examples: Orchids are the most beautiful flowers to me.
The boxed jellyfish is the most dangerous.
A quiet morning with coffee is the most relaxing.

subsections.title: THE MOST + noun
examples: Jackson earns the most money in the family.
The student with the most points wins.
subsections.explanation: 'The most' = number one in amount or quality.

subsections.title: Position in sentence
structure: (informal) mostly at front or end of sentence
examples: The tourists are mostly from the USA.
It's mostly egg white and sugar.
I mostly work from home.
We are mostly focusing on adverb position.
I wake up at seven, mostly.
Mostly, we just drink tea at book club.
subsections.explanation: Shows the main part or main amount.

subsections.title: ALMOST ALL + plural / uncountable noun
examples: Almost all dogs are cute.
Almost all water on Mars is ice.

subsections.title: ALMOST ALL OF + determiner + plural/uncountable noun
examples: He invested almost all of his money in the stock market.

subsections.title: ALMOST/NEARLY + adjective
examples: My plant is almost/nearly dead.
The tank is almost dry.

subsections.title: ALMOST/NEARLY + noun phrase
examples: I bought almost/nearly a year's worth of toilet paper.
She spends almost/nearly her whole salary on rent.
subsections.explanation: Use before the noun phrase you describe.

subsections.title: ALMOST/NEARLY + verb
examples: I almost said yes.
The house nearly collapsed.

subsections.title: ALMOST/NEARLY + adverb/time
examples: Our food is almost/nearly here.
It's almost/nearly 12 o'clock.
subsections.explanation: Usually interchangeable with the same meaning.

subsections.title: ALMOST before -ly adverbs (not nearly)
examples: She fixed the window almost soundlessly.
(Not correct: *nearly soundlessly*)

subsections.title: ALMOST LIKE
examples: It's almost like she doesn't work here.

subsections.title: ALMOST before negatives (never, no, none, nothing)
examples: Almost nobody orders the carrot cake.

subsections.title: NOT NEARLY (strong negative emphasis)
examples: That's not nearly enough food.
My running time is not nearly as good as last year.
